issues.description: The problem statement inconsistently refers to the animal feeding method as getFeedingSound(), while the UML, tasks, and solution code use messageOnFeed(). This name mismatch appears in multiple places in the problem description (instructions for implementing animal-specific feeding sounds and the description of feedAllAnimals()). Students may be unsure which method to implement (messageOnFeed() or getFeedingSound()) and which method feedAllAnimals() is expected to call, causing confusion when they try to follow the UML or the provided solution patterns.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across the problem statement, template, and solution. Preferably update the problem statement wording to refer to messageOnFeed() everywhere (replace getFeedingSound() occurrences with messageOnFeed()), and clarify that feedAllAnimals() should call messageOnFeed() on each Animal. Alternatively, if getFeedingSound() is preferred, update the UML, template stubs, and solution to use that name consistently. This resolves student confusion about which method to implement and call.

issues.description: The problem statement inconsistently refers to the animal feeding method as getFeedingSound() in several places (task descriptions for Seal/Pig/Goat and the song template) while the UML and the reference implementation use messageOnFeed(). This creates confusion about which method students should implement: the UML and solution expect an abstract messageOnFeed() in Animal and subclasses, but parts of the textual task describe getFeedingSound().
issues.suggested_fix: Make the feeding method name consistent across all artifacts. Prefer aligning the problem text to the UML and code: replace occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem statement (task descriptions and song template) with messageOnFeed(), and update the song template placeholders to indicate messageOnFeed() return values. Alternatively, if you prefer getFeedingSound(), rename the abstract method and all implementations in the template/solution to getFeedingSound(), and update usages accordingly. The least disruptive fix is to change the problem text to messageOnFeed().
